messages.content: Does subtracting a trend line create a misleading graph?

Subtracting a trend line from a set of data can create a misleading graph if the trend line is not an accurate representation of the underlying pattern in the data. For example, if the trend line is not a straight line or is not a good fit for the data, it can create the impression that the data is behaving differently than it actually is. Additionally, if the trend line is mis-scaled, it can also create misleading information.

It is important to use a trend line that accurately represents the underlying pattern in the data, and to make sure that the scale of the trend line is appropriate for the data. Additionally, it's important to consider the context of the data and the purpose of the graph, as well as any other information that might be relevant, in order to interpret the graph correctly.

In summary, subtracting a trend line from a set of data can create a misleading graph if the trend line is not a good fit for the data or is mis-scaled. It is important to use a trend line that accurately represents the underlying pattern in the data and to consider the context of the data and the purpose of the graph.
What if the trend is nonlinear?

If the trend is nonlinear, subtracting a linear trend line from the data can create a misleading graph. A nonlinear trend line would be more appropriate in this case as it better represents the underlying pattern in the data.

A nonlinear trend line can be estimated using a method called polynomial regression. Polynomial regression is a form of regression analysis that estimates a nonlinear equation to fit the data. It is based on the idea that the relationship between the independent variable and the dependent variable can be modeled as a polynomial function.

When using a polynomial regression, it is important to select the degree of the polynomial function that best fits the data. Higher degree polynomials will result in a more complex relationship, but may not be necessary if the curve is simple.

It is also important to note that nonlinear trend lines are not always the best fit for the data, and it's important to consider the context of the data and the purpose of the graph, as well as any other information that might be relevant, in order to choose the most appropriate trend line.

In summary, if the trend is nonlinear, subtracting a linear trend line from the data can create a misleading graph. A nonlinear trend line would be more appropriate in this case as it better represents the underlying pattern in the data. Nonlinear trend lines can be estimated using polynomial regression and it is important to choose the degree of the polynomial function that best fits the data.
Would it be misleading to have one axis in a 2D scatter plot at a non-orthogonal angle?

Yes, it can be misleading to have one axis in a 2D scatter plot at a non-orthogonal angle. This is because it can make it difficult for the viewer to compare the values on the two axes and can make it difficult to draw conclusions about the relationship between the two variables.

When one axis is at a non-orthogonal angle, it can make it more difficult for the viewer to compare the values on the two axes. This can make it more difficult to draw conclusions about the relationship between the two variables. For example, if one variable is on the y-axis and the other variable is on the x-axis, it can be difficult to determine if the values on the y-axis are increasing or decreasing.

Additionally, when one axis is at a non-orthogonal angle, it can also make it more difficult to distinguish between positive and negative values. For example, if one variable is on the y-axis and the other variable is on the x-axis, it can be difficult to distinguish between positive and negative values on the y-axis, which can make it difficult to make accurate conclusions about the relationship between the two variables.

In summary, having one axis in a 2D scatter plot at a non-orthogonal angle can be misleading because it can make it difficult for the viewer to compare the values on the two axes and can make it difficult to draw conclusions about the relationship between the two variables. It is important to make sure that the axes are orthogonal and that the scales are appropriate for the data.
What if the plot is intended to show the deviations in each point from the trend?

If the 2D scatter plot is intended to show the deviations in each point from the trend, then having one axis at a non-orthogonal angle could be misleading. In this case, it is important to have the trend line displayed in a way that allows the viewer to easily see the relationship between the two variables.

One way to show the trend line in a 2D scatter plot when the plot is intended to show the deviations in each point from the trend is to use a dashed or dotted line to indicate the trend, and to use a different color or style to distinguish it from the data points. This allows the viewer to easily see the relationship between the two variables, even if one axis is at a non-orthogonal angle.

Additionally, it is also important to make sure that the scales are appropriate for the data, and that the trend line is not mis-scaled.

In summary, having one axis in a 2D scatter plot at a non-orthogonal angle could be misleading when the plot is intended to show the deviations in each point from the trend. To show the trend line in a 2D scatter plot when the plot is intended to show the deviations in each point from the trend, it is important to use a dashed or dotted line to indicate the trend, and to use a different color or style to distinguish it from the data points. Additionally, it is also important to make sure that the scales are appropriate for the data, and that the trend line is not mis-scaled.
Then what would be a good way to show the relative error (per point) in a trend line drawn through points in a plot?

There are several ways to show the relative error (per point) in a trend line drawn through points in a plot:

1. Error bars: Error bars, also known as confidence intervals, can be used to show the range of possible values for each data point, which can help to indicate the uncertainty in the trend line.
2. Shaded regions: Shaded regions can be used to show the range of possible values for each data point, which can help to indicate the uncertainty in the trend line.
3. Residuals: Residuals can be used to show the difference between the observed values and the predicted values for each data point. A large residual would indicate that the trend line is not a good fit for the data point.
4. R-squared: R-squared is a statistical measure that indicates the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable that can be explained by the independent variable. A high R-squared value indicates that the trend line is a good fit for the data.
5. Confidence intervals: Confidence intervals can be used to show the range of possible values for the trend line, which can help to indicate the uncertainty in the trend line.
6. Standard error: Standard error can be used to show the range of possible values for each data point, which can help to indicate the uncertainty in the trend line.

It is important to use more than one method to show the uncertainty in the trend line, as each method has its own limitations and may not provide a complete picture of the uncertainty in the trend line.

In summary, there are several ways to show the relative error (per point) in a trend line drawn through points in a plot, such as error bars, shaded regions, residuals, R-squared, confidence intervals, standard error. It is important to use more than one method to show the uncertainty in the trend line and to consider the context of the data and the purpose of the graph.
Yes, I'd like to show the residuals of each point in the plot. Is subtracting the trend line still a bad idea?

Subtracting the trend line from the data points is not always a bad idea when trying to show the residuals of each point in a 2D scatter plot. In fact, it is a common way to create a line of best fit, which is a linear equation that represents the relationship between the two variables in the data.

When the trend line is subtracted from the data points, it can create a plot that shows the deviation of each data point from the trend line, which can help to indicate the uncertainty in the trend line. This can be particularly useful when the relationship between the two variables is non-linear, as a linear trend line may not accurately represent the underlying pattern in the data.

However, it is important to keep in mind that the residuals can be affected by the choice of the trend line model, for example, if the trend line is too steep or too flat, the residuals can be misleading. Additionally, it is important to consider the context of the data and the purpose of the graph, as well as any other information that might be relevant, in order to choose the most appropriate method for showing the residuals of each point in the plot.

In summary, subtracting the trend line from the data points is not always a bad idea when trying to show the residuals of each point in a 2D scatter plot. This can be a useful way to create a line of best fit which represents the relationship between the two variables in the data and can help to indicate the uncertainty in the trend line. However, it is important to keep in mind that the residuals can be affected by the choice of the trend line model, and to consider the context of the data and the purpose of the graph when choosing the most appropriate method for showing the residuals of each point in the plot.
